captions.text: [Intro]

For nearly forty years, New York City’s
Empire State Building was the tallest building

in the world. Topping out at 381 meters, it
now feels like something of a relic.

The tallest building currently under construction
-- Saudi Arabia’s Kingdom Tower -- will,

if all goes as planned, be more than 2 and
a half times taller than the Empire State.

Yes, we’re talking about a one-kilometer-tall
building.

How is that possible? And, how high can we
go?

The short answer to the second question is:
No one really knows. But a good look at the

Kingdom Tower and other super-skyscrapers
will give you a sense of the challenges that

come with building something that’s as tall
as, like, from here to the nearest Starbucks.

Kingdom Tower was originally conceived as
a mile-high building, or 1.6 kilometers, but

the project was scaled back after soil testing
revealed layers of weak, porous limestone
and sandstone underneath.

To provide a sturdy foundation for this ginormous
structure, 270 long concrete cylinders called

piles have been installed, as much as 1.8
meters in diameter and at depths up to 110
meters.

Working up from there, you have building materials
to consider. Three decades ago, the tallest

buildings on Earth were mostly made of steel.
But steel is crazy heavy, so today’s super-structures

are built mainly with concrete, or a combination
of steel and concrete.

Now, transporting concrete 800 meters above
the ground requires some creative engineering,

and it may be one of the trickiest limitations
to get past if we’re gonna go beyond the
1-kilometer mark.

For example, to construct the 828-meter Burj
Khalifa in Dubai -- currently the world’s

tallest building -- engineers had to invent
a 15-centimeter-wide pressurized tube to transport

wet concrete to the top. And they had to do
it all at night, so that in the heat of the

day, it wouldn’t dry en route to the 163rd
floor.

Some engineers say the future of building
materials may be in carbon-fiber composites,

the lightweight and super-strong materials
that are already used to build fancy bicycles

and modern airplanes. The downside is the
cost: Carbon fiber is very expensive.

And, even if a builder could afford enough
of it to get to one kilometer in height, there’s

still the question of how you keep the building
standing. Because the taller a building gets,
the harder it is to stabilize.

Wind in particular is a constant challenge
for building designers, and it’s more complicated
than just making sure the foundation is strong.

The tallest skyscrapers today have to regularly
withstand wind speeds over 150 kilometers
per hour.

To do that, most are built with joints at
the corners where steel beams can expand and
contract, allowing the building to sway.

That’s a good start. But you also have to
contend with wind vortices.

As the vortices keep moving, they quickly
separate from the building, and when they

do, each one essentially pulls the structure
toward it: These eddies of air end up yanking

the building from side to side, perpendicular
to the flow of the wind.

This is called vortex shedding, and you might
have seen its weird-looking effect on a flagpole
or light post on a windy day.

Wind-tunnel tests have helped engineers find
some solutions to the phenomenon, like rounded

edges and notches on a building’s face that
can act like wind-shock-absorbers.

But then, more practically, just about every
skyscraper architect will tell you about the
elevator problem.

I mean, you can build the world’s tallest
building, but if you can’t get people up

there to buy t-shirts, then … what’s the
point?

So, the elevator problem is two-fold: First,
elevator shafts can’t exceed 600 meters

in length -- at that point, the cables used
to move the cars just become too heavy to
work.

In the Burj Khalifa, engineers solved this
problem by creating what they call sky lobbies,

where passengers heading to the top get off,
and take a second elevator ride.

But modern super-scrapers are also limited
by elevator speeds. No one wants to take 15

minutes to get to work on the 120th floor.
But if you go too fast, then you’re talking

about air pressure and ear popping, not to
mention queasy passengers.

So most elevators don’t exceed speeds of
10 meters a second, and those have air pressure
controls and roller guides to dampen the vibrations.

To move people more quickly, one option may
be electromagnetically-driven elevator cars

that don’t need any cables. One company
has already created a prototype using technology

similar to the maglev motors on new train
systems.

So, it’s going to be 2019 at the earliest
when the world gets its first look at a kilometer-tall

building, and we can learn how engineers defeated
some, or hopefully all, of these problems.
Will we go higher? Probably.

But until someone comes up with super cheap
carbon fiber and perfects the electromagnetic

elevator, the steps are going to be incremental,
and few and far between.

Thanks for watching this SciShow Dose! If
you’d like to help us keep exploring the

frontiers of awesomeness, go to Subbable.com/SciShow
to find out how you can become a supporter.

And if you wanna keep getting smarter with
us, don’t forget to go to YouTube.com/SciShow
and subscribe!
